results.name: Progress MS-19 Docking
results.description: The Progress MS-19 spacecraft is scheduled to autonomously dock to the Poisk module of the ISS.

status.name: Go for Launch
status.description: Current T-0 confirmed by official or reliable sources.

mission.name: Progress MS-19 (80P)
mission.description: Progress resupply mission to the International Space Station.

program.name: International Space Station
program.description: The International Space Station programme is tied together by a complex set of legal, political and financial agreements between the sixteen nations involved in the project, governing ownership of the various components, rights to crewing and utilization, and responsibilities for crew rotation and resupply of the International Space Station. It was conceived in 1984 by President Ronald Reagan, during the Space Station Freedom project as it was originally called.

spacestations.name: International Space Station
spacestations.description: The International Space Station (ISS) is a space station, or a habitable artificial satellite, in low Earth orbit. Its first component was launched into orbit in 1998, with the first long-term residents arriving in November 2000. It has been inhabited continuously since that date. The last pressurised module was fitted in 2011, and an experimental inflatable space habitat was added in 2016. The station is expected to operate until 2030. Development and assembly of the station continues, with several new elements scheduled for launch in 2019. The ISS is the largest human-made body in low Earth orbit and can often be seen with the naked eye from Earth. The ISS consists of pressurised habitation modules, structural trusses, solar arrays, radiators, docking ports, experiment bays and robotic arms. ISS components have been launched by Russian Proton and Soyuz rockets, and American Space Shuttles.

program.name: International Space Station

results.name: NG-17 Cygnus Berthing
results.description: NASA TV will livestream the rendezvous and capture of Northrop Grumman's NG-17 Cygnus cargo craft to the International Space Station.

launches.name: Antares 230+ | Cygnus CRS-2 NG-17 (S.S. Piers Sellers)

status.name: Go for Launch
status.description: Current T-0 confirmed by official or reliable sources.

mission.name: Cygnus CRS-2 NG-17 (S.S. Piers Sellers)
mission.description: This is the 17th flight of the Orbital ATK's uncrewed resupply spacecraft Cygnus and its 16th flight to the International Space Station under the Commercial Resupply Services contract with NASA. This Cygnus spacecraft is named after American astronaut and climate scientist Piers Sellers. Sellers was a part of three Space Shuttle missions tasked with assembly of the International Space Station.

program.name: Commercial Resupply Services
program.description: Commercial Resupply Services (CRS) are a series of flights awarded by NASA for the delivery of cargo and supplies to the International Space Station.The first CRS contracts were signed in 2008 and awarded $1.6 billion to SpaceX for twelve cargo Dragon and $1.9 billion to Orbital Sciences for eight Cygnus flights, covering deliveries to 2016. The Falcon 9 and Antares rockets were also developed under the CRS program to deliver cargo spacecraft to the ISS.

results.name: US EVA-79
results.description: Two astronauts will venture outside the orbiting outpost to continue installation of the new iROSA solar arrays.
